title: 111_hr3133
content: The Act may be cited as the "Foreign Evidence Request Efficiency Act of 2009" and includes improvements to Title 18. Title 18 of the United States Code is amended to change procedures for court-issued warrants in investigations. Title 18 of the United States Code is amended to change procedures for court-issued warrants in investigations by specifying the jurisdiction and procedures for issuing warrants by a court of competent jurisdiction. Title 18 of the United States Code is amended to specify the jurisdiction and procedures for issuing warrants by a court of competent jurisdiction, including district courts of the United States. The amendment to Title 18 of the United States Code specifies the jurisdiction and procedures for issuing warrants by federal courts, including district courts and courts of appeals. The amendment to Title 18 of the United States Code outlines the jurisdiction for issuing warrants by federal courts, including district courts and courts of appeals. This includes provisions for warrants issued by courts in specific districts or for foreign assistance requests. The amendment to Title 18 of the United States Code expands jurisdiction for issuing warrants by federal courts, including district courts and courts of appeals, for specific offenses. The amendment to Title 18 of the United States Code expands jurisdiction for issuing warrants by federal courts, including district courts and courts of appeals, for specific offenses that fall under certain criteria. The amendment to Title 18 of the United States Code allows federal judges to issue warrants for foreign requests for assistance in criminal investigations and prosecutions. Federal judges can issue orders to execute requests from foreign authorities for assistance in criminal investigations or prosecutions, including proceedings related to forfeiture, sentencing, and restitution. Federal judges can issue orders in criminal proceedings, including search warrants and warrants for electronic communications. The Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure allow for the issuance of warrants for electronic communications, pen registers, trap and trace devices, and orders for testimony or document production. The Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure allow for the issuance of warrants for electronic communications, pen registers, trap and trace devices, and orders for testimony or document production. In response to a request from a foreign authority, a Federal judge may appoint a person to direct the taking of testimony or statements, or the production of documents. The Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure allow for the appointment of a person to direct the taking of testimony, statements, or production of documents. The appointed person has the authority to issue orders, administer oaths, and receive documents. The Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure authorize a designated person to oversee the collection of testimony, statements, and documents. This person can issue orders, administer oaths, and receive necessary documents or items. Requests for execution of foreign authority requests can be filed in the relevant district based on the location of individuals or materials involved. The Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure allow a designated person to oversee the collection of testimony, statements, and documents. Requests for search warrants from foreign authorities can be filed in the district where the person, documents, or things are located, or where a related Federal criminal investigation is taking place. An application for a search warrant from a foreign authority must be filed in the district where the place or person to be searched is located. A Federal judge can issue a search warrant only if the foreign offense involves conduct punishable by imprisonment in the United States. A Federal judge may issue a search warrant under this section if the foreign offense involves conduct punishable by imprisonment for more than one year in the United States. The warrant can be served anywhere in the United States, and nothing in this section prevents foreign authorities or interested persons from seeking assistance in criminal investigations or prosecutions. The section allows for search warrants to be issued by a Federal judge for foreign offenses punishable by imprisonment over one year in the US. Foreign authorities or interested parties can seek assistance in investigations or prosecutions under section 1782 of title 28, US Code. Definitions for 'Federal judge' and 'foreign authority' are provided. The term 'foreign authority' refers to a foreign judicial authority or an authority responsible for criminal investigations or prosecutions. The term 'foreign authority' refers to a foreign judicial authority or an authority responsible for criminal investigations or prosecutions. Criminal offenses, or an authority designated as a competent authority for making requests for assistance pursuant to an agreement or treaty with the United States regarding assistance in criminal matters. Foreign requests for assistance in criminal investigations and prosecutions.
